metadata.title: Global intervention on Kashmiris right to self determination urged

content.article_body: MUZAFFARABAD, Jan 05 (APP):A prominent Kashmiri activist on Sunday urged world leaders and global organisations to fulfil their longstanding commitments to the people of Jammu and Kashmir, whose right to self-determination remained unfulfilled for over seven decades. aSeventy-six years after the UN pledged to uphold the Kashmiri peopleas right to decide their future, that promise has been left to gather dust,a said Tanveerul Islam, a former chairman of United Jihad Council, an umbrella of groups fighting Indian occupation in Jammu and Kashmir. Mr Islam now heads not-for-profit Sawera Foundation, which which endeavours peacefully to promote the rights and welfare of the Kashmiri people. aThe Kashmiris remain ensnared in a cycle of oppression and political apathy, their voices silenced, and their aspirations ignored,a he said. Highlighting the aftermath of Indiaas revocation of Jammu and Kashmiras special status in August 2019, Mr Islam described the move as a catastrophic blow to the regionas political and cultural identity. aThe abrogation of Article 370 marked a turning point,a he said, adding, aIt stripped the occupied region of its autonomy and unleashed an era of intensified repression, which has been witnessing arbitrary arrests, custodial deaths, enforced disappearances, and the brutal blinding of innocent civilians with globally banned pellet guns.a The Sawera Foundation president also highlighted the plight of the Kashmiris who were forced to abandon their homes and hearths in the occupied territory and take refuge in Azad Jammu and Kashmir and Pakistan after 1989. aThe Kashmiris face systemic disenfranchisement. Not only those who are actively engaged in the freedom movement but their families as well, who are a permanent victim of threats, travel restrictions, and social ostracism.a aThe repression knows no borders,a he said. Mr Islam also drew attention to the grave socio-economic challenges facing Kashmiri youth, who he said were bearing the brunt of discriminatory policies that severely curtailed educational and employment opportunities. aIndiaas quota policies have reduced opportunities for Kashmiri Muslims by over 50%, leaving a generation in despair,a he said. Pointing out the fact that Kashmir remained the most heavily militarized zone in the world, with over 700,000 troops enforcing draconian laws like AFSPA and UAPA, he said this unchecked militarization had created a culture of impunity for human rights violations. Reiterating the gravity of the crisis, Mr Islam called upon the United Nations and international organizations to honour their promises and take decisive action. aThis is not just a regional conflictait is a humanitarian catastrophe and a global human rights crisis. The worldas silence has only emboldened repression,a he stressed. Reaffirming his organisationas unwavering commitment to the Kashmiri cause, he said the sacrifices of over 500,000 Kashmiris demanded justice in the shape of fulfilment of the promise made to them in 1949. aThe time for meaningful global intervention is now. Let us not fail the people of Kashmir againa, he added.
content.summary: A Kashmiri activist urged world leaders and global organizations to intervene and address the unfulfilled right to self-determination for the people of Jammu and Kashmir. He highlighted the impact of India's actions, including the revocation of Article 370 and the resulting human rights violations. The activist called for global action to address the humanitarian crisis and honor the promises made to the Kashmiri people.
